resources.string: \"Project Treble\" is a Google initiative aimed at making Android updates more immediate when a new version comes out. Project Treble is based on separating Android files from those strictly related to the device (vendor). Having the files necessary for the correct functioning of the device always safe in / vendor, it is possible to start generic Android images, broadly compatible with all devices: the GSI.

\"Superuser\" (or simply \"root\") is the system user who has administrator privileges. With root you have full control of your device, for example you can uninstall the pre-installed apps, you can change the device interface or other deeper changes to your liking.
BusyBox is a sort of Linux \"Swiss Army Knife\", in fact it contains in a small executable many Linux utilities (called \"applets\").

A/B partitioning ensures that you always have a functioning boot partition during an over-the-air (OTA) upgrade. In this way, the chances of having a device not working due to an unsuccessful update are drastically reduced. The main advantages of this system are:\n• possibility for the user to use the system even during the update (it will only be necessary to reboot to change partitions)\n• in case of an error during the update, the device will reboot again and return to the working partition
Choose how you want to get battery information. Keep in mind that the experimental methods is more accurate but may not work on all devices (%s)
This project is open-source: it means that the source code is visible to everyone and that anyone can contribute to it.

If you encounter a problem and want to report it, or if you want to suggest something to add, you can do it directly from here.
Write down here what you want to communicate (it\'s a problem you\'re having or function that you think should be added). Remember, every report is anonymous in full respect of your privacy.
